sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'; import ProgressUpdater from './ProgressUpdater'; import Hint from './Hint'; class GettingStarted extends React.Component{ constructor(props){ super(props) } render(){ return (
welcome to just for java! if you want to learn how to code but have no idea where to start, you're in the right place! and if you're cramming for your ap computer science exam tmrw, we gotchu. now, are you ready to learn java?

your journey begins in 3, 2, 1...

the first thing you need to do is create a just for java account! (btw: it's super easy. only takes 13 seconds.) here are the steps:
  1. see that button in the top right corner that says sign in with google? click it!
  2. bet you can't guess what this step is... sign in with google!
with your just for java account, you can now track and save your progress! pretty cool, eh? (btw: it took us super long to write the code to save your progress, so please use it a lot hehe.) want to start tracking your progress right now? change the progress dropdown menu above from todo to in progress. now, go to the home page and take a look at your progress table! you should see in progress next to getting started. oooooh fancy!! :) progress dropdown menus are located at both the top and bottom of every concept page.

bro when can i start coding?

soon bro. briefly, we just wanted to say why we created just for java. coding has the stigma of being complicated, hard to learn, and only useful for computer scientists. however, we want to break that stigma. this doesn't mean that coding will be easy, but we wrote the content in just for java using relatable language so it is easy to understand and fun for you guys! (btw: you may even see some jokes and text slang in there! *wink wink*) we provide blueprints to illustrate coding syntax and examples that we walk through so that you can master the concept. finally, coding is not only useful for computer scientists, but for everyone. oh, before we forget:
all the code we write during our examples will go in a box like this one! ;)

omg! it do be time for our first terrible coding joke!

coding is:
  • 10% coding
  • 35% debugging
  • 15% copy-and-pasted solutions
  • 40% staring at the screen
heheh. ok sry for killing one of ur brain cells...

recap

yo guess what?! you made it to recap! in recap, we give you a sparknotes version of what you learned – just a lil summary to help reinforce the coding concept.
if you're ever still bamboozled about the concept – which is completely okay – don't hestiate to email us! (psst. need a reminder on what our email address is? check out the contact us page!)

pit stop

in pit stops, we provide problems, and you get a chance to practice your coding skills. no stress if you have no idea what to do in these problems, because we always have hints that steer you in the right direction. in addition, we provide our solution which you can reference if you ever need extra help or if you want to check your code with ours. now let's do our first pit stop together!
your first repl:

so we've talked about coding in java, but where exactly do you type your code? your goal is to create your first repl using repl.it, a website where you can type and run your code (btw: the fancy name for this is a browser based IDE)! a repl is simply a coding project, so by the end of this pit stop problem, you would've created your first coding project! this will require five steps:
  1. navigate to the website repl.it
  2. create a repl.it account
    • click the sign up button; you can create an account with google
    • if you already happen to have a repl.it account, click the log in button
  3. navigate to the "my repls" tab, which is where you can see all of your repls
    • you can organize your repls into folders if you're obsessed with organization like we are ;)
  4. click the + button to create a new repl, which is a new coding project
    • you will be prompted to select the language that you want to code in and to name your project
    • feel free to name your project whatever you want :)
    • after this step you should be inside your new repl

our solution:

below is our solution for the problem above. the comments help to explain how to code each step. (psst. confused about what a comment is? don't worry about it for now because we're gonna talk about that next on the comments page!) hopefully your code looks similar to ours :)


ayy! since you finished the getting started page, go ahead and mark your progress as completed!

...we know just for java is as addicting as the newest Netflix binge, so what are you waiting for? get started coding!
) } } export default GettingStarted;
